docBody.head: Mrs. Sanger Urges Spread of Education for Relief
docBody.p: “The United States is particular about who comes into the country from the outside. It has found the selective quota to be a success. Why doesn’t it try a selective quota to judge who should come into the country from the inside?” Birth control, she explained, does not mean limiting the number of children in every family in the United States. It merely means the weeding out of the socially undesirable, the unwanted before their conception. The United States spent $9,000,000 in 1927 on the four D’s-- disease, defect, delinquency and death, and in the last three years has spent $18,000,000 in crime in one way or another. According to Mrs. Sanger, families that do not want more children, that have too many already, that cannot support them should be given a fair chance to limit their offspring. In the United States there are seven million children under fourteen years of age working in factories or in the field. Many of the parents of these children are getting wages scarcely sufficient to support themselves, much less a large family. Child-labor legislation is helpful in a way, but it does not go far enough. Mrs. Sanger mentioned the various ways of controlling and regulating the birth rate, and said that of course the Birth Control League did not intend to force anything upon people who did not wish it. In closing the speaker quoted Sir Arthur Heath who has declared: “There is developing in the United States the greatest experiment in race building the world has ever seen, and birth control is an integral part of that movement.”

div.head: Interviewer Notes Charm of Birth Control Advocate
div.p: “Birth control inspires parents to consider not only the physical welfare of the child, but to consider its inheritance and its potentialities as a race bearer.”

div.head: Noted Mrs. Sanger is Forum Guest
World Leader Will Present Problems Facing Youth
Forum Members Must Present Cards or Pay Admission
Lecture on Monday

p.q: Margaret Sanger, leader of the birth control movement in the United States, will speak in the chapel at eight o’clock, Monday evening, November 18. She is the author of several well-known books, “Women and the New Race,” “Happiness in Marriage,” “What Every Boy and Girl Should Know,” and has been for some years the editor of the Birth Control Review. In addition to her fervent written please for betterment of a situation to which people everywhere have been careless or wilfully blind for any number of years, Margaret Sanger has spent her life in crusading for this cause. After an extensive cultural and medical education and years of practical observation Mrs. Sanger is well qualified to speak with authority. She has endured notoriety and even arrest for her staunch views and clear speaking. She has traveled around the world and held many meetings in Japan and China, leaving birth control leagues in both countries. She organized in 1927 the first World Population Conference held at Geneva. She presents a problem of vital interest to all those concerned with the future welfare and happiness of the nation. The lecture is under the auspices of the Forum and all members will be admitted free of charge. Fifty cents admittance will be charged to all others wishing to attend Monday night. Tickets for the Forum’s season program will also be on sale at the door. Mrs. Sanger will be the guest of honor at a dinner given Monday night, at Hillside. Mrs. Dresser has opened her private dining room, and Sarah Holmes, President of Forum will be the hostess.
